author: Rodrigo Torrejon
title: Pilgrim Pipeline at center of debate in Oakland - Business
text:
Oakland – Leading into a decision to table an ordinance that would prohibit the installation of unregulated pipelines within the municipality's borders, council members questioned a related Planning Board vote taken by Mayor Linda Schwager.
At the Sept. 30 council meeting, after hearing members of the public comment on the ordinance — including those from a union representative of the Engineers Labor-Employer Cooperative — the council decided unanimously to table the ordinance for further review and potential revision by borough attorney Brian Chewcaskie. 
During its discussion, council members Pasquale Pignatelli and Timothy Jensen both cited a Sept. 10 Planning Board meeting in which the majority voted against formulating an opinion on the ordinance. Jensen and Eileen T. Rowin, a former mayor, voted to formulate an opinion. Schwager, who also sits on the board, abstained. 
The ordinance, which was introduced on Aug. 26, was formulated in response to a 178-mile pipeline system that has been proposed by Pilgrim Pipeline Holdings LLC. The dual pipeline system would extend from Albany to Linden, transporting Bakken crude oil through part of the Highlands region, including Oakland and Mahwah, to a refinery in Linden and return the refined product to Albany. 
The borough passed a resolution to "formally object and oppose" the project in October, but the more recent regulation would classify the pipeline as a "prohibited use." 
Jensen asked that the record of discussion at the council’s meeting include the Planning Board’s vote. Pignatelli, a Republican who is vying against Schwager, a Democrat, asked Schwager the reason for her abstention. 
"This council wanted an objective opinion from the Planning Board," said Schwager. "It was my opinion, and I said so at the Planning Board meeting, that I felt uncomfortable voting because you wanted an objective opinion from the Planning Board members as to whether or not this issue should come before the council as an endorsement. That is why I abstained."
At the following Oct. 8 Planning Board meeting, during a discussion to approve the minutes of the Sept. 10 meeting, Jensen said he perceived a discrepancy between the council discussion and his recollection of the Planning Board discussion
"I’m going to actually ask that we have the exact transcript," Jensen told the Planning Board. "I find the conversation listed here different from the conversation I recall in that the mayor actually never explained that it was about unregulated pipelines…I just want to be sure it’s accurately reflected, that’s all."
A majority of the board voted to table approval of the Sept. 10 minutes until Nov. 12. Board member Lee Haymon abstained.
